turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Sorry, son.  This is a matter for adults.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Officers, I've never said the P-word out loud, much less written it down!

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: No woman would!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Look officers! Life doesn't have to be ugly.  See the little birdie? Listen to his call.  Peter Pan! Peter Pan! Peter Pan!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Chip, your ride is here.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Hey, I'm late for work. Bye, honey.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Nothing like a home cooked meal, honey.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Misty, I made your favorite sesame broccoli...

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I can't stop thinking about that poor teacher.  Goodnight, honey. Don't read late, we've got a big day with the birds tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I've identified every little birdie we're going to watch tomorrow on the Eastern Shore.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Goodnight, honey.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Don't I get a kiss?

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I just thought with all the sadness... you wouldn't want...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We have to concentrate on life, Eugene.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: It's fine with me, Beverly.  You want to, honey? You think the kids are asleep?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We can be real quiet...

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I love that you're my wife.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You're not bad yourself, coo-coo bird...

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: You bring me such peace...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oohhhh, Eugene!

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Shhhh..

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oooohhhh.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Don't wake the kids...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Ooohhhh!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oooohhh! Yeah! Yeah!

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: You're hot tonight, honey... but be quiet! Shhhh! The kids!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Yeah! Oohhhh! Get it!

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Ooh, honey, I'm ready! Now! Now!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oohhhhh! Yeah! Yeah!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: There's Dede! He's my favorite chickadee! He's here every morning for breakfast.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Well, honey, chickadees breed in Alaska, you know. No wonder Dede's hungry. It's a long trip all the way to Baltimore.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: I'm sorry, honey. But the birds will still be there next week.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: It's Ok, Eugene. I understand... I'll go fix breakfast.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Let's say grace and pray that we have the strength to understand the terrible tragedies of the last few days.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Amen to that.  It's been a crazy day, hasn't it?!

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Beverly! Not the Sterners!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: It's a shame. But they should brush their teeth, honey.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Beverly, I've been reading all about it... is it menopause?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oh, honey!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Det. Bradford, I'm sorry but we don't allow gum chewing in this house.

turns.speaker: DET. BRADFORD
turns.text: Sorry, ma'am.  We're investigating obscene phone calls and mail threats to a certain Mrs. Dottie Hinkle.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I know Dottie!

turns.speaker: DET. BRADFORD
turns.text: Contusions... fractures... rupture of numerous vital organs...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What a mess.

turns.speaker: DET. BRADFORD
turns.text: Did you drive your car to the PTA meeting yesterday, Mrs. Sutphin?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: DET. BRADFORD
turns.text: "P" as in...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: ...People who don't mind their own business.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Well, this magazine was found in your trash just last night...  ...It's called "Chicks with Dicks".

turns.speaker: DET. BRADFORD
turns.text: GODDAMN YOU! THAT'S TRESPASSING!

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: Mrs. Hinkle, did you ever receive obscene telephone calls?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: I certainly did.

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: Did you recognize the voice of the caller?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Not at first, but then I heard the same inflection in a voice at a social gathering and I put two and two together.

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: Who's voice was it, Dottie?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: It was her! Beverly Sutphin! Sittin' right there!  I'm lucky I'm not DEAD!!

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: Objection! Argumentative!

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: NO I DON'T, YOU BITCH!

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Is this the Cocksucker residence?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Goddamn you! STOP CALLING HERE!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Isn't this 4215 Pussy Way?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: You bitch!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Let me check the zip - 212 Fuck you?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: The police are tracing your call right this minute.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Well, Dottie, how come they're not here then, Fuck-Face?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: FUCK YOU!

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: FUCK YOU TOO, YOU ROTTEN WHORE!!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Who is this?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Mrs. Wilson from the telephone company. I understand you're having problems with obscene calls.

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Yes, I am... I'm sorry Mrs. Wilson... It's driving me crazy... I've changed my number twice already... Please help me!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What exactly does this sick individual say to you?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: I can't say it out loud. I don't use bad language.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I know it's hard but we need the exact words.

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Alright, I'll try...  "Cocksucker". That's what she calls me.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Listen to your dirty mouth, you fucking whore!

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: GODDAMN YOU!

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: MOTHERFUCKER!!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: COCKSUCKER!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Just a half-a-cup.  Hello, Dottie. I'm so sorry to hear of your troubles...

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: It's not fair!!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Are those pussy-willows?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: What did you just say?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: PUSSY-willows, Dottie!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Dottie! Watch what you're doing!

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: I didn't do it!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: And we're going right to the flea market to get another one! Misty tells me there's a whole booth of Franklin Mint stuff. Dottie, you lock up.  I'll take care of poor Rosemary!

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: But... but... she... Rosemary, I heard her voice! It's her, I tell you, IT'S HER!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Mrs. Hinkle... do you drink?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: No, I don't.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: So you weren't drunk when you received those alleged obscene phonecalls?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: I certainly was not!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You mean to tell me the day I came over to Mrs. Ackerman's... the day you claim you recognized my voice... you weren't drinking?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: One beer with lunch is hardly "drinking".

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: So you do drink?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Socially... I'll have a beer.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: So you admit you just lied?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: Did you see her?! She just said "Fuck you" to me!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Let the record show I'm just standing here.

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: FUCK YOU TOO, YOU WHORE!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Mrs. Hinkle, are you insane?

turns.speaker: DOTTIE
turns.text: NO I'M NOT, YOU MOTHER-FUCKER!

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: State your name, please.

turns.speaker: MARVIN
turns.text: Marvin A. Pickles.

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: Were you in the men's room at the Edmonson Drive In Flea Market on Saturday, September 19th?

turns.speaker: MARVIN
turns.text: Yes, I was.

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: Mr. Pickle! Did you see anybody in the booth next to you?

turns.speaker: MARVIN
turns.text: I... I'm not sure...  ...I... oohhh... Excuse me...

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: What do you mean, you're not sure?!

turns.speaker: MARVIN
turns.text: Ooohhhhhh! I made it all up! I never saw Beverly Sutphin in my life!

turns.speaker: MR. NAZLEROD
turns.text: You'll pay for this, Marvin A. Pickles!  I'm turning your file over to the vice-squad!!  The prosecution rests, your honor.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Who wants fruit salad?

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: I do, please.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: That's not gum in your mouth, is it?

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: It's sugarless.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You know how I hate gum, Misty. All that chomping and cheesing...

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: Sorry, Mom. Thanks.  Hey, Chip, think I could get 50c for Vanilla Ice.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: And who may I ask is Carl?

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: Just a boy. He's picking me up this morning.

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: He killed people, Mom.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: We all have bad nights.

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: Yummy. Carl says if I lose ten pounds, he'll take me to the University of Maryland Fall Mixer.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Misty, if you want to lose weight go ahead, but do it for yourself, not for some boy you barely know.

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: I'm stoodup! I'll kill that bastard!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Don't say words unless you mean them, Misty.

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: It's him!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: No, honey, it's the police.  Hello, officers.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Damn these yellow-jackets! I hate 'em!

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: Always something isn't it?  Can I help you?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: It's just not your day, is it Rosemary?

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: Watch the booth! I'll be back!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: 0h, that's horrible, honey.  I sold the Pee-Wee Herman doll!!

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: Mother! Did you hear me?! Someone murdered Carl in the mensroom! I saw his dead body!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You got your wish.

turns.speaker: MISTY
turns.text: But...  I didn't wish... I didn't want him DEAD!

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: Beverly, are you alright?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Rosemary, honey. Good morning. I'm fine.  Thanks for remembering.

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: It's the least I could do.  I heard shouting.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Just the damn cable TV company. You know how they are. Did you hear about Dottie Hinkle?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: Yes, I did. It's terrifying! The police were at my house this morning.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Who on earth would want to harass poor Dottie Hinkle?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: That's like your car, Beverly,

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I'm not that bad a driver.  Look at her hair!  Turn it off, honey.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Did you find your Franklin Mint egg, Rosemary darling?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: I saw one, but it was ridiculously overpriced!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You want me to keep that under the table for you?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: If you wouldn't mind...  It was on sale.

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: Beverly, honey, you've got some...  ...do-do on your shoe.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Ewwww!  Thank you, Rosemary.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Mrs. Ackerman, when you left me at the flea-market, where did you go?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: ...Browsing.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Did Carl Padgett buy something you wanted?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: I didn't want that Faberge egg - it was chipped!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Carl Padgett died for the Franklin Mint, didn't he?!

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: NO! I could never hurt anyone!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: That was your People magazine with the letters cut out, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: Yes, but I lent it...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: And those were your scissors found sticking out of Mrs. Sterner's stomach, weren't they?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: Yes... but... I didn't...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Mrs. Ackerman, do you recycle?

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: No...  I don't have room in my kitchen...

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: Mrs... Sutphin?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Right here!

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: Mrs. Sutphin, I'm Paul Stubbins, Chip's math teacher.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Nice to meet you, Mr. Stubbins.  A little something I baked.

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: Oooohh! A fruit cake. Thank you, Mrs. Sutphin. Have a seat.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Bon Appetit!

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: Chip is off to a fine start this year.  Focused... conscientious... participates actively in classroom discussion.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: He's a good boy.

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: There is one big problem though.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What is it, Mr. Stubbins?

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: His unhealthy obsession with sick horror films.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: He is assistant manager of a video shop...

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: That's no excuse for a morbid imagination. I caught him drawing this in class last week.  Is there a problem at home?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Certainly not!

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: Divorce? An alcoholic relative?  Tell me, did Chip torture animals when he was young?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: No, he did not! We are a loving supportive family, Mr. Stubbins.

turns.speaker: MR. STUBBINS
turns.text: Well, you're doing something wrong, Mrs. Sutphin. I'd recommend therapy for your son.  Thank you for taking the time to come to PTA.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I don't know what it is about today, but I FEEL GREAT!

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Excuse me, Mrs. Sutphin.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Man, that one made me puke!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You forgot something...

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Are we leaving?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Yes you are.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: SHE DID IT! Aimed the car right at Mr. Stubbins and mowed him down!

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: From what I understand, the eye- witness is a drug user.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Murder, honey.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Now, here's a babe!

turns.speaker: MRS. STERNER
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: MR. STERNER
turns.text: I didn't hear anything. Got any dessert?

turns.speaker: MRS. STERNER
turns.text: Dr. Sutphin said no sweets for you.

turns.speaker: MR. STERNER
turns.text: What's he know?

turns.speaker: MRS. STERNER
turns.text: How to send a bill!!

turns.speaker: MR. STERNER
turns.text: What is it, Betty?

turns.speaker: MRS. STERNER
turns.text: We have mice! I mean it, Ralph! I saw one!

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: Young man, this Faberge Egg is chipped.

turns.speaker: VENDOR
turns.text: Yes, ma'am, it is.

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: I'll give you fifty cents.

turns.speaker: VENDOR
turns.text: That's a Franklin Mint piece. Eight dollars.

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: Eight dollars?! Franklin Mint or not, it's damaged goods!

turns.speaker: MRS. ACKERMAN
turns.text: I'll take this instead.

turns.speaker: VENDOR
turns.text: Nice one, huh? Winter's coming.  Three dollars?... I guess that's what I marked it...

turns.speaker: RADEAU
turns.text: You know who I am, August?

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Sure I do.

turns.speaker: RADEAU
turns.text: Then you know that if I give you a little advice, it'll be good advice.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Yeah - sure.

turns.speaker: RADEAU
turns.text: That girl was looking for Jacqueline Gibson. I'd forget it if I were you.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Okay, Mr. Radeau, it's forgot.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: The name may not mean anything to you, young lady, but say the word and I'll have your sister for you in forty-eight hours.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You can?

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Look, sister', Manhattan is only nine miles long and four and one half miles wide. I ain't never been off it. I know it like you know your own back yard. You get me a small retainer --say fifty bucks, and I'll get your sister for you. I guarantee

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I haven't any money but I'll get a job and --

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: I've been waitin' for you Miss Gibson. I want you to know I've decided to take your case.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Mr. August, I'm not at all sure -

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Look. Don't say a word. I've taken an interest in you and I'm willin' to put up my time to help you. Besides, I think I know where to find your sister.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Wait a minute. This has got a lot of angles. You've got to take it easy. Do you know a Mrs. Redi?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes. She bought my sister's business.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: That's what she told you. I looked it up at the Hall of Records. Your sister deeded her the business as an outright girt.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why would Mrs. Redi lie to me?

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: That's what I tried to find out.	I went to La Jeunesse   -- used a phony health inspector's badge  they let me go through the works -- all but one room. That room was locked. I'd like to see the inside of that room.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You think my sister is there?

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: You can't tell.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Can we go there now?

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Sister, you can't just go breaking into places. There's a night watchman down there and locks on the door.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: If my sister's in that room, it won't make any difference about warrants- and things, I want to go there.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: I don't know if I want to go with you or not.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: I don't like this.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Which room is it?

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: It's the last door at the end of this hall.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: You scared?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Let's get out of here.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's only a little way, Mr. August.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: I'd like to get out of here.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: We can't stand here all night.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You could go and open the door.

turns.speaker: AUGUST
turns.text: Listen 

turns.speaker: BRUNS
turns.text: The acceptance of a secret is an obligation and in this case my dear, the obligation carried with it the necessity of dying if one betrayed that secret. You understand that don't you?

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: Yes, I understand.

turns.speaker: BRUNS
turns.text: Then, you also understand that you must die.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: When I wanted to.

turns.speaker: BRUNS
turns.text: It doesn't matter. You want to now. You should want to. It's your obligation, your duty.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: May I have some water? I'm thirsty.

turns.speaker: BRUNS
turns.text: Drink.

turns.speaker: JACQUELINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BRUNS
turns.text: You won't get any water and you won't get any rest. You may as well drink.

turns.speaker: MISS SUMMERS
turns.text: Mr. Ward will see you in just a few minutes. Won't you wait, Dr. Judd?

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MISS SUMMERS
turns.text: Are you Dr. Louis Judd?

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MISS SUMMERS
turns.text: I read your book. The one in which you wrote about the cure for drinking.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: You're not a dipsomaniac at your age?

turns.speaker: MISS SUMMERS
turns.text: No. It's my father -- I wanted to talk to you -- you wrote about cures --

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: I've come from Jacqueline. She needs money.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I thought you told me you didn't know where she was.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: I didn't. She came to me a few days ago. To put it delicately her care imposes a financial burden upon me. She thought you might lighten that burden.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: If Jacqueline wants money she can come to me herself.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: I'm afraid she can't do that, Ward. It would endanger her.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: What sort of danger?

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: You're a curious man. You're willing to jeopardize Jacqueline's life in order to satisfy your own curiosity.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: You come to me with some wild story about her being in danger - naturally I want to know what kind of danger. I want to know where she is.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: It's not just for myself I'm asking. Her sister is here. The kid's half crazy with anxiety.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: As a man, you distrust me - perhaps you believe me as a physician.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: Well, then I can tell you that in addition to other dangers, there is a grave danger of Jacqueline losing her sanity. I would advise against you seeing her.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: But why? She's been ill --erratic, but I've never heard of anything like that!

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: How much does she want?

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: She could use a hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I'll give you a check.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: She can only use cash.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I haven't got that much in cash.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: How much have you got?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: About forty-five dollars.

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: For the time being, I imagine that must do.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Tell me, how is Jacqueline?

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: Oh, as beautiful as ever.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: But tell me --

turns.speaker: DR. JUDD
turns.text: She's nervous, naturally, under the circumstances.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: What circumstances?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: Why, Mary --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hello, Frances.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: How's Miss Jacqueline?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't know. That's why I came to see Mrs. Redi. I'm trying to find her.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: You mean Miss Jacqueline's gone, and you don't know where she is?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: I don't get this. Miss Jacqueline was always so fond of you -- she was always talking about you - had your picture in her office.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I know. For the first time I'm beginning to be frightened. I almost feel as if I'd never known my sister.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: Nothing's happened to her. It's just that I can't understand her not getting in touch with you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can't understand it at all.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: Well, don't worry. I saw Miss Jacqueline only a week ago. I saw her at a little restaurant the boy friend took me to -- an Italian place down in the Village -	"The Dante."

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: "The Dante?"

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: It's on Peary Street. Just ask the people who run it. They'll remember her.  People who see Miss Jacqueline never forget her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll try there.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: I can't see much fun in teaching school. Why don't you go into the beauty business.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But I like teaching school.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: Well, if it's fun for you, it's all right. I get a kick out of my work when the customers aren't too crabby.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is Mrs. Redi nice to work for?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: Redi's all right.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: She seems rather an odd woman to me.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: She's a pretty good sort.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What does she do with herself after business hours?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It always seemed to me she was sort of lonely and unhappy.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: I guess most people are.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: The tip is, anyhow. I like to work on your hair.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Do you know what this is, Frances?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: I ought to know.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: What did she want?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: I did her hair.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: What were you talking about?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Nothing! That's absurd. I heard you laughing and talking, She was asking questions.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: She was just asking about you - Whether it was nice to work for you or not.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: And that was all?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: No. She asked about the trademark.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: What did she want to know?

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: She showed me a drawing.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: You	fool! That symbol is us -- us. She was asking about us.

turns.speaker: MRS. REDI
turns.text: Some of us, Frances, must believe without understanding.

turns.speaker: FRANCES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: We're not exactly strangers, Mary. Jacqueline spoke about you often. I suppose she told you about me,

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No...At the morgue they told me a Mr. Gregory Ward had made inquiries about Jacqueline.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: The Morgue? No wonder you fainted.  I wish you had come to me first.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Then you know where Jacqueline is?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: But I'd give a great deal to know.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I love your sister, Mary. I love her very much.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: A man would look anywhere for her, Mary. There is something exciting and unforgettable about her - something you never get hold of - something that keeps a man following after her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Because I loved Jacqueline I thought I knew her. Today I found out such strange things frightening things. I saw a hangman's noose that she had hanging - waiting  I feel as if I'd never known her.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: At least I can explain that, Mary. Your sister had a feeling about life  that it wasn't worth living unless one could end it. I helped her get that room.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Weren't you afraid?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Afraid she might commit suicide?  People who commit suicide don't talk about it. That room made her happy in some strange way I couldn't understand. She lived in a world of her own fancy. She didn't always tell the truth. In fact - I'm afraid she didn't know what the truth was.  There were many things about Jacqueline I didn't understand, and yet, without understanding, I had to be with her  to see her  to touch her  in order to be happy. It's hard to explain to a youngster.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm not a youngster. I can understand.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thank you. It was a lovely dinner.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But I reel guilty. It doesn't seem right for me to enjoy myself with Jacqueline gone.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: You can't make it your life's work looking for Jacqueline.  ) You'll have to do other things... live...get some enjoyment out of life. I hope you'll let me help you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thank you.. .goodnight.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Goodnight, Mary.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: This is about another murder  a woman at Fifty Second Street

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But you do believe me?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: The important thing is, the police won't believe you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I saw him on the floor. He was cut -  --here. The blood was running out. He was dead. I'm sure of it. Then on the subway I saw him  white  and the men holding him up between them.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Yes, of course  but the police would say you'd probably had a bad dream.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He was a kind little man in his way  and I made him go down that hall into the darkness. I made him do it.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Drink your milk.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I'm sorry. I didn't intend to treat you like a child.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But you have treated me that way.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: I won't do it again. We're friends. I'll never order you about again.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: However, I won't say that I'll not take charge occasionally, and I'm going to take charge new. I've a job for you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: A job?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: You told me you were pretty good with youngsters. Today I bumped into an old friend of mine, Mrs. Wheeler  She runs a settlement house down in the Village and is looking for a kindergarten teacher.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'd like that.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: It's not much money, but it's enough to live on. You'd have to move out of that hotel and into a furnished room.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Maybe the Romaris might have a room. They seem nice.

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: The people at the restaurant?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What brought you down here, Greg?

turns.speaker: GREGORY
turns.text: Oh, I had business with a man... but I missed him -

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, I'm glad you came to see me.
